awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Biotic and abiotic drivers of Neotropical plant speciation
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants are the foundation for terrestrial biodiversity, and the forests of Central and South America are home to more types of plants than anywhere else in the world. Over very long time periods, this diversity of plants is produced by speciation, the complicated process whereby one species becomes two. This project will test ideas about how speciation happens in tropical forests. It will also greatly increase basic knowledge of how plants cope with different environments and how they interact with insects that pollinate their flowers and eat their leaves. Many undergraduate and graduate students, especially those from underrepresented groups in science, will participate in the project, gaining research experience and career training. The team will work to increase international capacity in biodiversity science by helping with field courses in Latin America, involving local research assistants at each tropical field site, and organizing an international research symposium in Costa Rica.  Finally, investigators will broadly communicate their experiences and scientific findings to the general public.  Results will help guide conservation and management of tropical forests, which are rapidly changing due to human influences.

Two evolutionary hypotheses for high tropical speciation rates have been proposed. First, because tropical climates are relatively stable year-round, organisms may not evolve the ability to tolerate a wide range of climates and therefore may not disperse widely. Local populations will then become isolated from their relatives and gradually become new species. Alternatively, interactions between plants and other organisms, such as pollinators and herbivores, may vary from place to place, such that a population adapted to one biological community will grow and reproduce poorly when it spreads to another community. In this way, there may be natural selection for plants in different locations to become different species. This research uses spiral gingers in the monocot genus Costus in Costa Rica and Panama to test these hypotheses about tropical speciation. Spiral gingers occupy a wide range of habitats, extending from lowlands to montane forests and from dense understory to forest edges, with different temperature, water, and soil conditions. They interact with many different orchid bee and hummingbird pollinators, highly specialized beetles that feed on young leaves, and ants that provide protection from herbivores in exchange for nectar. This work integrates phylogenetic studies, broad scale observational approaches, focused field experiments (reciprocal transplants and direct manipulations of interacting organisms and abiotic factors), and genetic mapping. It will determine how plants interact with and adapt to pollinators, herbivores, ant protectors, and climatic conditions across their geographic ranges. It will evaluate whether speciation is caused by traits and genes that have positive effects in one environment and negative effects in other environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The remarkable diversity of plants in the tropical Americas is the foundation for diversity at all other trophic levels, yet the evolutionary mechanisms responsible for this diversity are poorly understood. In this study, we used spiral gingers in the genus Costus to investigate biotic and abiotic drivers of speciation, adaptation and diversification in the American tropics. 

When testing for biotic drivers of diversification, we found that pollinator shifts from bee to hummingbird pollination in Costus are common and are consistently associated with speciation across the clade. Furthermore, we found that repeated, parallel evolution of complex floral traits are associated with pollinator shifts. These findings support the role of biotic drivers of diversification across the tropical spiral gingers and suggest that plants may repeatedly adapt to novel pollinators through similar evolutionary pathways.

An alternative to biotic drivers of diversification in the tropics are abiotic factors. Specifically, steep climate gradients and climate stability in mountainous tropical regions may facilitate diversification. Consistent with this idea, we found greater Costus diversity in topographically complex regions, and so further tested two additional hypotheses: 1) that stable tropical climates have led to species having narrow climatic tolerances, and thus their ranges can easily be dissected by topographic dispersal barriers leading to eco-geographic isolation and speciation; 2) that steep climatic gradients in tropical mountains lead to species diverging in climate niche across fine-scale gradients, with strong selection and tradeoffs among climate niche traits contributing to speciation. Interestingly, we did not find clade-wide support for either of these abiotic hypotheses in Costus, with mountain-influenced sister species displaying similar levels of climatic divergence as lowland sister pairs.  However, when exploring adaptation of individual species pairs along abiotic gradients we are finding instances of strong local adaptation and fitness tradeoffs associated with eco-geographic isolation. These fitness trade-offs due to climate and habitat are stronger than those associated with herbivores or pollinators per se. We conclude that abiotic factors likely contribute to species formation and diversification for most species pairs, and that biotic factors such as geographic variation in herbivores and pollinators strengthen these fitness trade-offs.

Our evolutionary genetic investigations of this group of plants show that even though one can easily hybridize species in the greenhouse, in the wild, they remain isolated species because of their ecological differences. This isolation is maintained despite low levels of gene flow among species, especially those that share pollinators. We investigated the genetic basis of ecological differences among species, and find that biotic adaptations, such as changes in flowers to attract different pollinators or changes in nectar rewards to attract ant defenders, are due to a few genetic changes of large effect. In contrast, physiological and life history adaptations to different abiotic habitats tends to be caused by many genetic changes of small effect. Our project provides the first data on speciation genetics in a tropical plant group, and the genomic resources we have developed, including three new reference genomes, will facilitate evolutionary research in the American spiral gingers for years to come.

Our project has had a large impact on the scientific development of many early career scientists, including postdocs, graduate students, and undergraduates. We are especially proud of the training we have provided to Latinx scientists, given that the plants we are studying are native to Latin America. We have helped place new faculty at several universities across the country, and our graduate and undergraduate students have launched successful scientific careers.
